page_analysis.text_content:
Recessed porches on the 1st floor

Recessed porches on the ground floor do NOT count toward
gross floor area if ALL the following criteria apply:
• Depth of porch is less than 10' and,
• Porch ceiling is below 2nd floor and,
• Exterior side is substantially open.

Fig 9 Recessed porches on the 1st floor

Note: It is the city's policy to consider
one-story construction to be construction
less than 17' above finished floor. If the
porch space is higher, the area will count
again as 2nd story equivalency.

2nd floor line
Porch ceiling
below 2nd floor

2nd floor line

A This example complies with all three
criteria and does NOT count toward
gross floor area

Depth < 10'

Height extends past
2nd floor line

B This example violates two of the three criteria.
• the porch depth is greater than 10' and
• the porch ceiling is above the 2nd floor
Therefore it DOES count toward gross floor area and
if it is higher than 17' it will count twice (see note).

Depth ≥ 10'

14

visual_elements.description: An isometric architectural drawing showing a house with a recessed porch on the ground floor. The porch is depicted with a depth less than 10 feet and its ceiling is clearly below the 2nd floor line. An arrow points to the porch ceiling with the label 'Porch ceiling below 2nd floor'. Another arrow indicates the depth of the porch with the label 'Depth < 10''. This diagram is labeled 'A' and described as an example that complies with all three criteria and does NOT count toward gross floor area.

An isometric architectural drawing showing a house with a recessed porch on the ground floor. The porch is depicted with a depth greater than or equal to 10 feet and its ceiling extends past the 2nd floor line. An arrow indicates the height extending past the 2nd floor line with the label 'Height extends past 2nd floor line'. Another arrow indicates the depth of the porch with the label 'Depth ≥ 10''. This diagram is labeled 'B' and described as an example that violates two of the three criteria, specifically that the porch depth is greater than 10' and the porch ceiling is above the 2nd floor. It states that this porch DOES count toward gross floor area and if it is higher than 17' it will count twice.

sections: Recessed porches on the ground floor do NOT count toward gross floor area if ALL the following criteria apply:

Note: It is the city's policy to consider one-story construction to be construction less than 17' above finished floor. If the porch space is higher, the area will count again as 2nd story equivalency.
Fig 9 Recessed porches on the 1st floor

additional_notes: Page number '14' is located at the bottom left.

qualifiers.text: Recessed porches on the ground floor
It is the city's policy to consider one-story construction to be construction less than 17' above finished floor.
If the porch space is higher

conditions.text: Depth of porch is less than 10'

logical_relationships.expression: if (c1 AND c2 AND c3) THEN Recessed porches on the ground floor do NOT count toward gross floor area
IF (c4) THEN the area will count again as 2nd story equivalency

execution_sequence.action: Evaluate if a recessed porch on the ground floor meets the criteria for not counting towards gross floor area.
If the porch space is higher than 17' (regardless of whether it counted towards gross floor area initially), apply 2nd story equivalency.
